\hypertarget{love-letter-making-room-for-more-love-and-sheep}{%
\section{Love Letter: Making Room for More Love (and
Sheep)}\label{love-letter-making-room-for-more-love-and-sheep}}

And, a legacy of ``Loving'' continued.

\href{https://www.nytimes.com/by/charanna-alexander}{\includegraphics{https://static01.nyt.com/images/2020/03/18/reader-center/author-charanna-alexander/author-charanna-alexander-thumbLarge.png}}

By \href{https://www.nytimes.com/by/charanna-alexander}{Charanna
Alexander}

\begin{itemize}
\item
  July 31, 2020
\item
  \begin{itemize}
  \item
  \item
  \item
  \item
  \item
  \end{itemize}
\end{itemize}

Living in a picturesque farmhouse on many acres of land may sound like a
dream to some. But many couples who live and work on fully functioning
farms know it's anything but glamorous. Tending to the day-to-day
demands of a farm, including caring for several different animals, can
take a toll on any relationship.
\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/31/style/modern-love-spending-tenderness-on-animals.html}{In
this week's Modern Love essay}, Bethany Groff Dorau, a writer who grew
up on a farm, questions whether her city slicker husband is cut out for
the rural life. Then they decide to adopt three sheep.

In the five decades since the legalization of interracial marriage in
the United States, many interracial couples,
\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/31/fashion/weddings/Renee-Knake-and-Wallace-Jefferson-wed-tribute-to-Lovings-before-them.html}{including
Renee Knake and Wallace B. Jefferson}, thank Mildred Loving and Richard
Loving, who effectively challenged interracial marriage laws in the
1960s.

Ms. Knake and Mr. Jefferson were married July 4 outside of the Michigan
governor's summer residence on Mackinac Island, Mich., where they paid
homage to the Lovings during their ceremony by sharing statements
dedicated to their fight for interracial marriage. ``I can't imagine
what it would be like to be so profoundly and deeply in love as I am
with this man and to have to feel like I was committing a crime,'' Ms.
Knake said.

{[}\emph{Like this newsletter?}
\href{https://www.nytimes.com/newsletters/love-letter?module=inline}{\emph{Sign
up}} \emph{to receive it in your inbox.{]}}

And, if you're thinking about checking in on a friend or family member
who is going through a difficult time right now,
\href{https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/28/smarter-living/coronavirus-how-to-check-in-with-a-friend.html}{here's
how to create the right atmosphere} so your loved ones feel comfortable
opening up, even if you're not able to connect in person.

\hypertarget{we-want-to-hear-from-you}{%
\subsubsection{\texorpdfstring{\textbf{We want to hear from
you.}}{We want to hear from you.}}\label{we-want-to-hear-from-you}}

We want to deliver content that truly matters to you and your feedback
is helpful. Email your thoughts to
\href{mailto:loveletter@nytimes.com}{\nolinkurl{loveletter@nytimes.com}}.

Also, here's how to
\href{https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/jO3tQFgT0oTtrEkB_1KMDg~~/AAAAAQA~}{submit
a Modern Love essay} or how to be featured in
\href{https://nl.nytimes.com/f/a/VUmOvPA8RQFKQ8aEcY3i7Q~~/AAAAAQA~_alz1eu4c4e1IXZW1tYS5ncmlsbG9Abnl0aW1lcy5jb21YBAAAAAA~}{an
Unhitched column}. Don't feel like writing more than a tweet, an
Instagram caption or a Facebook post? Consider
\href{https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/950f6-aK170HA-bgDMlF_Q~~/AAAAAQA~}{submitting
to Tiny Love Stories}, which are no more than 100 words. Getting
married? Here's how to
\href{https://nl.nytimes.com/f/newsletter/er3_tn9RUSsoSb6-Pk2jUA~~/AAAAAQA~_alz1eu4c4e1IXZW1tYS5ncmlsbG9Abnl0aW1lcy5jb21YBAAAAAA~}{submit
a wedding announcement.}an 100 words.
